climbs.name: Stockholm Syndrome SDS A.K.A. Never Too Far From Hugh-Manatee

content.description: Start sitting left Hand on slopy hold with a good thumb catch and right on a good crimp. jump and slap your way up the boulder topping out the Manatee's "Face"
content.location: This is to the left of the steep bulge.

content.description: Stand start the steepness and make a hard topout.
content.location: This ascends the steepest bulge on the Manatee Boulder.

content.description: Stand start with a good left fin and a good, right hand, flat hold.
content.location: Start a few feet left of the bulge.

content.description: Sit start matched in a good finger crack, bump left to an obvious good hold, move up, and make a tough topout.
content.location: This ascends the face about 8-10 feet left of steep bulge.

content.description: Stand start with a semi-hidden left hand crimp and your right on the arete. Move straight up.
content.location: If you are facing the steep bulge on the Manatee Boulder, walk at 11 o'clock for about 150 feet.

content.description: Sit start the steep boulder using a good right foot wedged between the split boulders and a high left crimp and a low right hand on the arête. Power straight up, and top out.
content.location: It is about 200 feet from the Southwest Arête.

pathTokens: Cavalry Boulder Field aka Gymnasium aka Playground

content.description:
This rock is named for its resemblance to the docile sea-cow.  

  There are, as of yet, no routes on this boulder. However, the potential for a tough and slopey sit-start is certainly there. 

  This boulder is included in the database as a landmark on your way to finding the Extensions 3 Boulder along the Extensions trail.  

  I added it as its own area/crag due to the likelihood that SOMEONE will find something to climb on it, even it that person is not me.  

  So, get after it and put your name down for the FA of this most cumbersome of mammals. 

  (Or just walk by it and feel glad that you're not lost.)
